intro: Bactris chocoensis, commonly known as the Chocó palm, is a species native to the tropical regions of Central and South America. It is a member of the Arecaceae family and is characterized by its tall, slender trunk and large, pinnate leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that are arranged in inflorescences, followed by edible, round fruits that are similar in appearance to cherimoyas. Bactris chocoensis thrives in humid, shaded environments and is often found in lowland rainforests. Its botanical features make it an important component of the ecological diversity in its native habitats.
